course_title: Culture, Identity and Power in the Ancient World

learning_outcomes.description: Students develop a deep understanding of the influences of Greco-Roman and wider Mediterranean cultures on both the ancient and modern worlds, in conjunction with acquiring advanced discipline skills, through working critically, comprehensively, and ethically with diverse types of ancient evidence, and with a range of ancient and modern historical, archaeological and material culture models and methodologies.

Through the critical evaluation of diverse types of ancient evidence, theoretical models, methodologies, and ideas, students test and challenge a number of traditional assumptions, not only about the influence of the Greco-Roman world on the wider Mediterranean and vice-versa, but also about the influence of the Greco-Roman world on the modern world.

Students engage critically with complex cultural and social issues faced by disempowered and/or disenfranchised groups and communities who populated the Mediterranean broadly controlled by Rome from the last century BCE to the 3rd Century CE, and through this knowledge, are encouraged to become culturally aware citizens capable of innovative and positive social change in the modern world.

Students demonstrate discipline-based and transferrable advanced-level research, thinking, data management and analysis, and problem-solving skills to produce high quality oral and written work for different audiences using evidence-based forms of persuasion.

Students are encouraged to become respectful, inspirational leaders by working collaboratively and independently on problems which raise ethical questions about how the history of the ancient and modern worlds has been shaped or recorded, particularly in relation to marginalised ancient social and cultural groups, and indigenous Australian and Torres Strait Islander groups.

Students demonstrate and showcase professional development skills, literacies, and achievements by working collaboratively and independently on a variety of research and in work-integrated learning activities, and by completing authentic assessment tasks to develop transferrable workplace skills.

Alongside developing advanced transferrable workplace skills in digital technologies, students reflect upon the ethical implications of applying different methods of communicating the outcomes of historical, archaeological, and material culture research to different audiences.

assessments.assessment_title: Professional Eportfolio Part 1: Writing For Different Audiences
assessments.task_description:
Writing for different audiences is an important, transferable workplace skill that is important not only outside the University, but also in academia. For example, preparation for participation in meetings, workshops, seminars, and conferences usually requires preparatory reading and the preparation of concise reports, presentations, posters, and/or applications, many of which have strict word-limits. Some reports are also reflective in nature, asking about how an experience has helped you build skills or look towards future development. We will be practicing concise and reflective writing skills in tutorial workshops.

This two-part task requires you write a research essay and then turn it into a poster for a different audience.

Further details are available on Blackboard, and will also be discussed in class.

After receiving feedback, students will include these assessment items in their E-portfolio WordPress Showcase.

Students are not required to rewrite these assessment items, but should correct any spelling, grammar, and factual errors if necessary after they are marked.

Posters will also be printed and displayed at the Annual Ancient History Day organised by our UQ Alumni Group, The Friends of Antiquity.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. Using AI for the writing components of this assessment task does not meet the learning objectives. AI generated images may be used for the poster, if appropriate, and if discussed beforehand with Dr McWilliam.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

It must also include and Introduction ('About Me' and 'My Goals' Sections), a CV (CV's are not assessed), and Employability Critical Reflections based on the interviews available on Blackboard.

You will be required to provide the url link to your WordPress Portfolio in order for it to be marked for assessment. Please make sure it is accessible for marking.
